caseTitle: NANA SARPONG GYAMFI, KRONTIHENE, AKYAWKROM AND ASENUA, ASHAN
summary: In this 2000 Supreme Court of Ghana case, Nana Sarpong Gyamfi, the Krontihene of Akyawkrom and Asenua, brought an action against Nana Kwaku Dakore II (also known as Kwaku Okyere), the Gyasehene, seeking a declaration that the defendant was disqualified from holding chieftaincy office due to a prior conviction for an offence involving moral turpitude. The defendant had been convicted in 1986 by the Circuit Court, Kumasi, and his appeal was dismissed by the High Court in 1990. The plaintiff argued that under Article 275 of the 1992 Constitution, such a conviction disqualified him from being a chief. However, the Supreme Court held that although the claim was framed constitutionally, its substance involved a chieftaincy matter, over which the court lacks original jurisdiction pursuant to Section 66 of the Chieftaincy Act 1971 (Act 370). The court therefore declined jurisdiction, affirming that such disputes must be resolved by the appropriate traditional councils and regional houses of chiefs.
verdict: The Supreme Court declined jurisdiction, ruling that the matter falls under chieftaincy law and must be adjudicated by traditional judicial bodies, not the Supreme Court.
winningSide: Defendant (by default, as the court refused to hear the case on jurisdictional grounds)
rationaleHighlights: The Supreme Court lacks concurrent original jurisdiction over chieftaincy matters under Section 66 of Act 370.
